'''''The New Lemminkainen''''',<ref name=collectedpoems>{{CP|8}}, pp. 38-48</ref> also known as '''''Lemmincaignen færeþ to bróþar sínum on Súþlanden''''',<ref name="list">{{CP|A3}}, pg. 1378 (list "A")</ref> is a parodic<ref name=collectedintro>{{CP|Introduction}}, p. xvi</ref> poem of a train<ref name=collectedintro/> journey<ref name=collectedintro/> written by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] in [[September]] of [[1911]].<ref name=chronology>{{CG|C}}, p. 28 (entry "September 1911")</ref>

==Poem excerpt==
''Runo I''

''Argument: Lemminkainen boards the fire-consumer, known as Puffpuff the million-footed.''
<poem style="font-style:italic; margin-left:20px;">
:Then the skittish Lemminkainen,
:He the handsome Grecian hero,
:He whose other name was Hermes,
:Thus did speak and burbled thiswise,
:Thus endeavoured to express him,
:To express his grief and anger
:To address the iron dragon.<ref name=collectedpoems/></poem>

==Background==
Sometime soon after reading Kirby's translation of the ''[[Kalevala]]'',<ref name=collectedpoems/> [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] wrote the poem '''''The New Lemminkainen'''''<ref name=collectedpoems/> as a parody of the translation.<ref name=chronology/> Tolkien wrote "Lemminkainen goeth to his brother in the Southlands" as the poem's general argument "on the first page of" the poem's manuscript.<ref name=collectedpoems/> In a poetry notebook,<ref name=collectedpoems/> Tolkien described the poem as "Lemminkainen goeth to the Lands of Ilma the Smith and Kemi the Brook (being some lost runos of the Kálevalá) (parody on Kirby's translation in "Everyman" series)"<ref name=collectedpoems/> and "dated the poem to"<ref name=collectedpoems/> [[September]] of [[1911]].<ref name=chronology/> After the abrupt end of the poem, Tolkien wrote the partially legible line "His brother with the" before heavily striking it through, and the words "see scrap for end" despite there being no scrap.<ref name=collectedpoems/>

In [[October]] of 1911, Tolkien wrote ''[[Lemminkainen Goeth to the Fords of Oxen]]'',<ref name="list"/> a second poem about Lemminkainen going on a train journey.<ref>{{CP|9}}, p. 49</ref> In a list of poems marked "''[[Ungefeged inne]]''" that were probably "contemporary with" another list labeled "[[Attempts at Verse]]", Tolkien included ''The New Lemminkainen'' and named it ''Lemmincaignen færeþ to bróþar sínum on Súþlanden'' in [[Old English]].<ref name="list"/>

In [[2006]], the poem was first mentioned by [[Wayne G. Hammond]] and [[Christina Scull]] in ''[[The J.R.R. Tolkien Companion and Guide]]'' as '''''The New Lemminkäinen'''''.<ref>{{CG|Po}}, "By Title", p. 852 (entry "''The New Lemminkäinen''. Unpublished.")</ref> In [[September]] of [[2024]], the poem was published for the first time as entry 8 in ''[[The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien]]'', where its spelling was corrected.<ref name=collectedpoems/> In a note to Runo I, Hammond and Scull explain that "a ''runo'' (rune) is a poem, or part of a longer poem" and that "''Puffpuff'' is slang…for a locomotive".<ref>{{CP|8}}, note "Runo I, Argument:"</ref>

==Inspiration==
In a [[1914]] paper, Tolkien referred to Lemminkäinen as "a confirmed villain of loose morals and wife-beating propensities as the lively Lemminkainen (as he is always called) shows only his best and most affectionate feeling for his mother".<ref>''[[The Story of Kullervo]]'', "[[On 'The Kalevala' or Land of Heroes]]"</ref> In their commentary in ''[[The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien]]'', Hammond and Scull explain that while Tolkien's version of [[Wikipedia:Lemminkäinen|Lemminkäinen]] is also lively, he is skittish,<ref>{{CP|8}}, note "1:"</ref> lacks "the loose morals of his namesake", and the spelling of his name lacks an unlaut.<ref name=collectedpoems/> In a note on their "Addenda and Corrigenda to ''The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien''", Hammond and Scull stated that by "unlaut", they had meant "diaeresis".<ref>{{webcite |author= [[Christina Scull]] and [[Wayne G. Hammond]]|articleurl= https://www.hammondandscull.com/addenda/collected_poems_by_date.html|articlename= Addenda and Corrigenda to ''The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien'' (2024) Arranged by Date|dated= 24 December 2024|website= HS|accessed= 31 December 2025|archiveurl= |archivename= |archivedate=}}, "'''p. 45''', l. 15 from bottom: For 'umlaut' read 'diaeresis'."</ref> The mention of Lemminkainen being a "Grecian hero…whose name was Hermes" is likely an allusion "to Tolkien's performance as the Greek god [[Wikipedia:Hermes|Hermes]] in [[Wikipedia:Aristophanes|Aristophanes']] play ''Peace'' at King Edward's School on [[26 July]] 1911".<ref>{{CP|8}}, note "2-3:"</ref>
